snippet: Drug makers say a system of discounts intended for low-income and uninsured patients is being abused, but hospitals say they can’t do business without it.
abstract: Drug makers say a program known as 340B, which requires them to provide discounts of 20 to 50 percent to hospitals and clinics that treat low-income and uninsured patients, is being abused; pharmaceutical industry wants to rein in the discounts, but hospitals insist that they cannot do business without them and would have to cut services without the program.
lead_paragraph: Drug makers say a system of discounts intended for low-income and uninsured patients is being abused, but hospitals say they can’t do business without it.
